Situation1: They have a serious conversation about financial or health decisions that require full transparency and mutual understanding.
Expectation2: Write clean, maintainable, and efficient code
Situation2: A critical service is slowing under load and traces point to their recently merged functions
Story: I sat at the kitchen table, laptop open, my fingers hovering over the keyboard. My husband’s voice echoed from the living room, “Can we talk now? It’s important.” I knew what he meant—our finances had been tight, and he wanted to go over the numbers together, to make sure we were both on the same page. He expected honesty, openness, and my full attention. But my mind was tangled in lines of code. Just an hour ago, my manager had pinged me: the new service I’d written was causing slowdowns, and the team was waiting for me to fix it. The pressure was immense; I was expected to deliver clean, efficient code, and any mistake could ripple through the whole system. I glanced at the clock, feeling the weight of both worlds pressing in. My husband’s trust depended on my transparency, but my team’s trust depended on my technical competence. My heart pounded as I tried to decide which expectation to meet first, feeling the pull of both roles, knowing I couldn’t give either the attention they deserved.
